channel.title: NYT > Home Page
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: ArtsBeat: Netflix Does Well in 2013 Primetime Emmy Nominations
item.description: The online network Netflix officially joined its cable and broadcast counterparts on Thursday, picking up a best drama nomination for the political thriller “House of Cards.”
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN STELTER
item.media:description: Kevin Spacey and Robin Wright were both nominated for their roles in "House of Cards."

item.title: Judge in Manning Case Allows Charge of Aiding the Enemy
item.description: The military judge in the trial of Pfc. Bradley Manning decided on Thursday not to drop a charge accusing Private Manning of “aiding the enemy.”
item.dc:creator: By ERIN BANCO

item.title: City Room: New York Today: Be Cool
item.description: What you need to know for Thursday: Unusual places to cool off on another very hot day, Nelson Mandela’s 95th birthday and a lost chicken is rescued in Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH MASLIN NIR
item.media:description: Any shade will do: escaping the sun on a non-tropical island on Ninth Avenue.

item.title: DealBook: Dell Adjourns Vote on Deal as Some Big Investors Start to Shift
item.description: Dell adjourned a vote on its proposed $24.4 billion sale to its founder on Thursday morning, signaling that the planned transaction lacked enough support from shareholders.
item.category: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation|BK|NYSE
Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED
item.media:description: Michael S. Dell, the founder of the computer company that bears his name.

item.title: Insurgents Kill 8 Afghans Near U.S. Base
item.description: Eight Afghan men heading to work at an American base on Thursday morning were pulled from their car by insurgents and killed, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: DealBook: Morgan Stanley Posts 42% Rise in Profit and Sets Stock Buyback
item.description: Morgan Stanley reported adjusted earnings for the second quarter that slightly beat analysts’ estimates, driven by a strong performance from its wealth management unit and equity sales and trading.
item.dc:creator: By SUSANNE CRAIG
item.media:description: James Gorman is the chief executive of Morgan Stanley.

item.title: DealBook: In Energy Case, a Fresh Tactic by JPMorgan: A Push to Settle
item.description: JPMorgan Chase wants to settle accusations by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission that it gleaned profits from power plants via “manipulative schemes.”
item.dc:creator: By BEN PROTESS and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG
item.media:description: It is unclear whether FERC will pursue a separate action against Blythe Masters, a senior JPMorgan executive.

item.title: Steam Detected at Damaged Fukushima Reactor
item.description: The operator of the ravaged nuclear plant in Japan stood ready Thursday to inject boric acid into the reactor if temperature or radiation levels rose.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Russian Court Convicts Opposition Leader
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most resonant opposition voice and a Moscow mayoral candidate, was sentenced to five years in prison on embezzlement charges.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most resonant opposition voice and a Moscow mayoral candidate, reacts as the court delivers the verdict on Thursday in Kirov, Russia.

item.title: Mandela Said to Be ‘Steadily Improving’ on 95th Birthday
item.description: After weeks battling critical illness, Nelson Mandela spent his 95th birthday in the hospital on Thursday, and South Africans across the country celebrated Mandela Day.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN and ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A crowd sings "Happy Birthday" to Nelson Mandela, the former president of South Africa, outside the Mediclinic Heart Hospital in Pretoria.

item.title: Voters Approve of City’s Progress, Poll Finds, but Seek Empathetic Mayor
item.description: Sixty-one percent of voters said a candidate’s ability to understand the needs and problems of ordinary New Yorkers was the most important factor in the race.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID W. CHEN and MEGAN THEE-BRENAN
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The poll found Christine C. Quinn leading among Democratic voters by nine percentage points.

item.title: Russian Opposition Leader Navalny Found Guilty
item.description: A Russian judge on Thursday found opposition leader Alexei Navalny guilty of theft, a ruling that could send the charismatic anti-corruption blogger and Moscow mayoral candidate to prison for up to six years.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Southern California Wildfire Forces Evacuation of Mountain Resort
item.description: A fast-growing wildfire in the mountains of Southern California forced the evacuation on Wednesday of the popular resort community of Idyllwild after flames engulfed seven homes and numerous other buildings.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: In China and U.S., Mutual Distrust Grows, Study Finds
item.description: A Pew survey found that since 2011, China’s approval rating in the United States dropped to 37 percent and negative attitudes toward the United States among the Chinese rose to 53 percent.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Racial Disparities in Life Spans Narrow, but Persist
item.description: Higher rates of death from heart disease, cancer, homicide and diabetes help explain the 3.8-year gap in life expectancy between black and white Americans.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Steamy Wait Before a Walk in a Museum’s Rain
item.description: Waits are hours long for “Rain Room,” an installation at the Museum of Modern Art that has rain falling all around, but miraculously, not on you.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE L. BELCOVE
item.media:description: “Rain Room” at the Museum of Modern Art, the destination for visitors who line up for hours.

item.title: Florida Case Spurs Painful Talks Between Black Parents and Their Children
item.description: The acquittal of George Zimmerman in the fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin has rattled any sense of security for black families, with parents even warning sons what not to wear.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON
item.media:credit: Dan Gill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christian Hayes, 24, of University City, Mo., who has twin sons, said if someone were following him, “I’m not going to run.”

item.title: Judge Expected to Decide on Charge of Aiding Enemy
item.description: The judge hearing the case against Pfc. Bradley Manning said she would decide Thursday on his lawyers’ request to drop a charge accusing him of aiding the enemy.
item.dc:creator: By ERIN BANCO
item.media:description: Pfc. Bradley Manning outside court in Maryland on Monday. He gave documents to WikiLeaks.

item.title: Watchdogs Seek Doping Clues From a Distance
item.description: A group of activists is scrutinizing the Tour de France for hints of doping by comparing current performances with past ones. But the fairness of their methods has been questioned.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES DAO
item.media:credit: Charlie Shoemaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ross Tucker, a 32-year-old physiologist, reflected in his TV during a Tour broadcast. Tucker said uncomfortable questions were what the sport needed to clean up its image.

item.title: Building Blocks: A Transit Hub in the Making May Prove to Be the Grandest
item.description: The expansive main hall at the World Trade Center complex could become a destination in its own right.
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
item.dc:creator: By DAVID W. DUNLAP
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: The World Trade Center Transportation Hub, with a $3.94 billion price tag, is to open in 2015. It originally was to cost $2 billion.

item.title: Bipartisan Backlash Grows Against Domestic Surveillance
item.description: Lawmakers from both parties called for the collection of the private data of millions of Americans to be scaled back.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES RISEN
item.media:description: Representative Jim Sensenbrenner, Republican of Wisconsin, was among the lawmakers who expressed skepticism about the collection of private data by the National Security Agency.

item.title: Momentum Shifts in Syria, Bolstering Assad’s Position
item.description: Though his country is in shambles, President Bashar al-Assad now seems better positioned to hang on to power than he has been for most of Syria’s two-year civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Syrian Arab News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad's resilience suggests that he has carved out what amounts to a rump state in central Syria that is firmly backed by Russia, Iran and Hezbollah.

item.title: In Minor Leagues, a Rich Man Visits a Frayed City
item.description: Playing with Class AA Trenton, Alex Rodriguez, armed with the richest contract in baseball history, found himself plying his trade in one of the country’s poorest cities, Reading, Pa.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT CACCIOLA
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Rodriguez after a game with the Class AA Trenton Thunder in Reading, Pa.

item.title: Winners and Losers: Politicians Are Slowed by Scandal, but Many Still Win the Race
item.description: Across the country, politicians have faced opponents tainted by scandal — some of them seemingly muddied beyond saving — yet they have gone on to lose anyway.
item.dc:creator: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON
item.media:credit: Left, Chris Aluka Berry for The New York Times; right, Rich Addicks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Sanford, the former South Carolina governor who admitted to having an extramarital affair, defeated Elizabeth Colbert Busch in a Congressional race in May.

item.title: Advertising: Apple’s Move Into TV Relies on Cooperation With Industry Leaders
item.description: Apple’s steps to reimagine television, like teaming up with ESPN, stand in stark contrast to efforts by Google to compete with established companies.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN STELTER
item.media:description: An app lets users stream Sky News through Apple TV, giving the network access to viewers without dealing with cable providers.
